Climate change is real. Human activity is the dominant cause. Congress must act. 

Now let‚Äôs get to work.

To the American people: Don‚Äôt be fooled or distracted by these political games. We cannot allow cynicism to win. We can reduce our nation‚Äôs carbon footprint, strengthen our economy and support those most vulnerable among us.

The president‚Äôs failed leadership on #climatechange threatens our health, our economy, U.S. competitiveness and our future. And sadly, most of our @SenateGOP friends have been applauding the president with every action.

Instead of pursuing any ideas to #ActOnClimate, this administration has:
‚ùå ignored climate science
‚ùå defunded clean energy research
‚ùå rolled back climate action
‚ùå walked away from provisions that would help protect Americans from rising floods and other extreme weather events

Scientists tell us that unchecked climate change means more frequent and intense storms ‚Äì meaning bomb cyclones, intense rainfalls and category five hurricanes become the new normal. No matter where we live, we can‚Äôt ignore the reality of climate change. #ClimateChangeIsReal

If we do not #ActOnClimate, climate change could slash up to 10% of our GDP by 2100 ‚Äì that is double the losses of the Great Recession. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/23/climate/us-climate-report.html¬†‚Ä¶

According to our nation‚Äôs leading scientists, climate change unchecked means more sea level rise ‚Äì costing coastal communities like the ones in my state trillions of dollars in economic damages over the next 80 years. #ActOnClimate https://www.newsweek.com/rising-seas-could-cost-world-14-trillion-year-2100-1006823¬†‚Ä¶

According to @NOAA:

üö® In 2017, extreme weather cost Americans $300 billion in economic damages
üö® The federal government spent $120 billion in disaster spending for four extreme weather events in 2017
üö® These numbers will be a drop in the bucket if we do not #ActOnClimate

A clear majority of Americans want Congress to address our growing #climatecrisis. We should be having a fact-based, policy-driven conversation about tackling it. And we should be talking about the real costs that confront us ‚Äì including the costs of inaction.

Sadly, some of our GOP colleagues have been trying to make a mockery of the very real concerns and passionate calls to #ActOnClimate we‚Äôre hearing from people across the country and around the world. On an issue as serious as this one, we should be serious about addressing it.

When I was a Naval Flight Officer stationed outside San Francisco waiting to be deployed to Southeast Asia during the Vietnam War, I celebrated the first-ever Earth Day. As I hear the rising chorus of calls for #climate action, I hear the sounds of that day in Golden Gate Park.

Getting ready to join @VelshiRuhle to discuss my bipartisan report on @Equifax‚Äôs inadequate cyber security practices, which led to a cyberattack that compromised sensitive information of more than 145 million Americans. pic.twitter.com/nPYDZTsuok

Both private and public entities should feel a sense of urgency to bolster their cyber defenses. Congress, the Administration, and American businesses need to work together to put in place nationwide cybersecurity standards to protect consumers.

It‚Äôs my hope that, by shedding light on @Equifax‚Äôs cybersecurity failures that led to this devastating data breach, other U.S. companies can avoid similar breaches that leave millions of American households exposed to hackers.

.@Equifax‚Äôs two largest competitors ‚Äì @TransUnion and @Experian ‚Äì received the same information about potential vulnerabilities, took proper steps to secure their systems and, to date, have avoided a breach.

In 2015, @Equifax learned it had thousands of cyber vulnerabilities, but did not address those known security issues.
 
Unsurprisingly, in 2017, @Equifax experienced a massive breach that exposed the sensitive data over 145 million Americans.

You would think that protecting the sensitive information its entire business relies on would be @Equifax‚Äôs top priority. Yet my report with @senrobportman illustrates years-long neglect of basic cybersecurity practices. https://www.carper.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/pressreleases?id=C21B82E3-F715-4D72-AA12-DDB7963B15EB¬†‚Ä¶

If someone shops regularly at a retail chain that gets hacked, that person can opt not to shop there any longer if doing so makes them uncomfortable. They cannot, however, keep their information away from @Equifax.

When hackers obtain someone's person information, the consequences are real. The constant stream of data breaches we see year in and year out are a sign to me that we could and should be doing a lot better.

It is my hope that, by shedding light on @Equifax‚Äôs inadequate cybersecurity practices that led to this devastating data breach, other U.S. companies can avoid similarly devastating breaches that leave millions of American households exposed to hackers.
